resources.string: Gorgonzola is a town in the Metropolitan City of Milan, in Lombardy. It has around 20500 inhabitants called gorgonzolesi.\nGorgonzoeula (IPA: [ɡurɡũˈdzøːla]) is the name of the town in the dialect spoken around Milan. Sometimes the town is also called GorgoTown by some, in an affectionate and informal fashion.\nBesides the characteristic city centre, the territory of Gorgonzola includes the hamlets of Frazione Riva, Località Produttiva, Cascina Mugnaga, Cascina Vergani, Cascina Nuova e Cascina Antonietta.

Gorgonzola is located at 133 m above sea level, 13 Km North – East of Milan in the Martesana territory, once called Martesana county.\nThe Naviglio della Martesana, an artificial canal, and the torrent Molgora flow through its flat territory.\nThe Pre – Alps of Bergamo and Lecco and Valtellina are not faraway to the North.

According to most Gorgonzola is the birthplace of the blue cheese, for sure it had been the main centre of its production and trade for many centuries.\nOriginally called Stracchino di Gorgonzola, and then also Stracchino verde, gorgonzola cheese was produced with the Autumn milk of the weary (stracch in dialect) cows during the transhumance from the summer mountain pastures.\nGradually its production extended to an area ranging from Piedmont and Lombardy and which is now defined and protected by the PDO mark and the \"Consorzio per la Tutela del Formaggio Gorgonzola DOP\", which has also set the processing procedure to obtain the famous blue cheese.

Gorgonzola is the most North Eastern town belonging to the Parco Agricolo Sud Milano, which includes the land of the towns and villages of the Southern half of the metropolitan belt surrounding Milan.\nHere agriculture is the main activity supporting the protection of the environment and the landscape, even if there are also untouched and protected areas, giving the park a high plant and animal biodiversity.\nTourism is of a rural and naturalistic kind.

In The Bethrothed by Alessandro Manzoni, chapter XVI, it is told that Renzo, fleeing from Milan where he was involved in a riot and risked to be arrested, headed to Bergamo, in the Republic of Venice, and stopped for dinner in an inn in Gorgonzola.

The Naviglio della Martesana is a distinctive feature of identity of the territory it passes through.
It is a 38 Km long artificial canal, that receives the waters from the River Adda in Concesa, a hamlet of Trezzo d'Adda, it crosses the Martesana territory and arrives as far as Milan, where it integrates into its now largely underground water system.
Its construction began under the Duke of Milan Francesco Sforza in 1457, it was navigable from 1482 and completed in 1496 under Ludovico il Moro, although a few important adjustments were made afterward.
At those times the Martesana territory was important not only for the agricultural activity, but also for its strategic position, close to the border with the Republic of Venice.
The Naviglio has been important to move the millstones, presses of crushers, spinning machines and paper mills, to connect Milan to the River Adda and the Lake of Como, to move people, food supplies and goods back and forth.
With time it attracted the noble families who established their country residences next to it.
The boats covered the entire journey from Trezzo d'Adda in 7 and a half hours, from Milan in 12 hours driven by two horses.\The naviglio is no longer navigable since 1958, while remaining very important both in collecting, regulating rainwater and for irrigation purposes.
Sanctuary of Our Lady of Help

This little one nave church was once dedicated to Saint Peter and was part of an ancient Umiliati's convent, perhaps it was its chapel.
Its foundation dates back to the XII century.
A part of the convent is still visible in the beautiful Corte dei Chiosi.
In the XVII century Francesco Maria Abbiati, the Bishop of Bobbio who was born in Gorgonzola, donated a reproduction of the painting of the Sanctuary of Bobbio depicting Our Lady of Help, to which the little Sanctuary was later dedicated, due to popular devotion.

Ca'busca, as Villa Serbelloni Busca Sola Cabiati is commonly called, was the country residence of the ancient and noble Serbelloni family from Milan.
It is composed of a main building, a system of rural courts, a sixteenth century tower, a covered wooden bridge that crosses the Naviglio della Martesana.
It was purchased by the municipality in the second half of the XX century.
Part of it houses the headquartes of the public library, in part it was fractioned into private housing units.
The beautiful park of the Villa has become a much loved public garden.

In his last will in 1802, the Duke Gian Galeazzo Sebelloni assigned lands and funds in order to build a church and a hospital.
His daughter Maria Luigia began to build the hospital in 1848, also thanks to the donations of the Legato Pio Serbelloni and the Opera Pia Gagnola.
Its execution was entrusted to the architect Giacomo Muraglia, who conceived an elegant structure with medical and hygienic standards which were very advanced in those days.
In 1975 this historic building was judged no longer suitable for its functions and since then the hospital activity has taken place in a more modern structure.
Chiesa Prepositurale SS MM Gervasio e Protaso

This is the main Church of the town and it was built in substitution of an older one, which dated back to the X century.
The new Church was made according the last will of Gian Galeazzo Serbelloni by his daughter in 1806.
Its construction was entrusted to architect Simone Cantoni, and completed in 1820 by Giacomo Muraglia who also build the bell tower.
It consists of an elegant and harmonious structure in neoclassic style.
The Serbelloni Mausoleum stands at one of its sides, the Naviglio flows on the other side.

The villa, which stands parallel to the Naviglio was already mentioned as one of the properties of the Fregnaneschi family in 1722 in a land register.
As time went by it subsequently became property of other families.
During the latest decades of the XX century the palace was fractioned into several housing units. It has been under tutelage since 2002.
The subsequent restoration work has given new glory to this building of neoclassical appearance,and has brought to light a few decorative elements reputed lost.
The ground floor is property of the municipality.

Every year since 1998, around the third weekend of September there is a big party in town, the streets get populated by many people who come to celebrate the famous blue cheese in his hometown, from which it took its name.\nCrowded and cheerful, it\'s an end of Summer party full of events, stalls, good food, good wine and beer, but above all so much gorgonzola cheese.

In 1785 a new fair was established, which became an important annual appointment in which agricultural goods and products, diary, court and working animals were bought and sold.\nSince then every year Saint Catherine Fair takes place on the weekend around the 25 November, the day dedicated to the Saint of Alexandria of Egypt.\nNowadays the agricultural element of the is much less pronounced, nonetheless it keeps being a very heartfelt, cheerful fair which marks the passage fromm deep Autumn to Winter.
